raw_text:
Japanese growth grinds to a halt
 
 Growth in Japan evaporated in the three months to September, sparking renewed concern about an economy not long out of a decade-long trough.
 
 Output in the period grew just 0.1%, an annual rate of 0.3%. Exports - the usual engine of recovery - faltered, while domestic demand stayed subdued and corporate investment also fell short. The growth falls well short of expectations, but does mark a sixth straight quarter of expansion.
 
 The economy had stagnated throughout the 1990s, experiencing only brief spurts of expansion amid long periods in the doldrums. One result was deflation - prices falling rather than rising - which made Japanese shoppers cautious and kept them from spending.
 
 The effect was to leave the economy more dependent than ever on exports for its recent recovery. But high oil prices have knocked 0.2% off the growth rate, while the falling dollar means products shipped to the US are becoming relatively more expensive.
 
 The performance for the third quarter marks a sharp downturn from earlier in the year. The first quarter showed annual growth of 6.3%, with the second showing 1.1%, and economists had been predicting as much as 2% this time around. "Exports slowed while capital spending became weaker," said Hiromichi Shirakawa, chief economist at UBS Securities in Tokyo. "Personal consumption looks good, but it was mainly due to temporary factors such as the Olympics. "The amber light is flashing." The government may now find it more difficult to raise taxes, a policy it will have to implement when the economy picks up to help deal with Japan's massive public debt.
llama3.2:1b: Japanese economic growth has stalled in three months to September 2023, sparking concerns about an economy not yet out of its decade-long trough. The country's output grew by just 0.1%, down from a 6.3% first quarter and 1.1% second quarter, with exports failing to pick up pace. Domestic demand remains subdued, corporate investment falls short, and the economy is heavily reliant on exports for recent growth. High oil prices have knocked off 0.2% of growth, while the falling dollar makes US products more expensive. The performance marks a sharp downturn from earlier in the year, as economists had predicted at least 2% growth this time around.
llama3.2:3b: Japan's economic growth slowed in Q3, falling to 0.1% annual rate as exports and domestic demand lagged behind expectations. This marks a sixth consecutive quarter of expansion but is below forecasts. The economy remains dependent on exports, which are affected by high oil prices and the strong US dollar, leading some economists to warn that raising taxes will become more difficult when the government tries to stimulate the economy further.
gemma2:2b: Japan’s economic growth has stalled, growing just 0.1% in the third quarter of the year, resulting in renewed concerns about the economy. Exports are faltering and domestic demand is weak, while corporate investment also declined. This marks a sixth consecutive quarter of expansion but falls well short of expectations. The slow economic growth is likely linked to long-term deflation and reliance on exports for recovery.  High oil prices and a falling dollar are affecting export competitiveness.  The government faces difficulties raising taxes to reduce public debt.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Japanese growth has slowed down in September. According to the text, the economy had stagnated throughout the 1990s and experienced only brief spurts of expansion during long periods of doldrums. As a result, Japanese shoppers are cautious about spending due to high prices falling rather than rising. The performance for the third quarter shows a sharp downturn from earlier in the year compared to previous quarters. The government may now find it more difficult to raise taxes as the economy picks up to help deal with Japan's massive public debt.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Japan's economic growth has halted in the three months to September, experiencing negative 0.1% annual expansion after six straight quarters of growth. The slowdown is marked by flat exports and subdued domestic demand, leading economist Shirakawa calling it an "amber light" signal for the economy, which may struggle to raise taxes when growth picks up due to high public debt.
qwen2.5:3b: Japanese growth grinds to halt, marking sixth straight quarter of expansion despite recent positive indicators. Growth in the three months to September was 0.1%, annual rate of 0.3%. Exports stalled, domestic demand remained weak, and corporate investment fell short. This follows a decade-long economic downturn characterized by deflation and reliance on exports for recovery. Recent growth has been hampered by high oil prices and a falling dollar affecting US markets. Economists predict further slowdowns, with the government facing challenges in raising taxes due to public debt concerns.
opencoder:1.5b:
The Japanese growth in Japan has dipped in the three months to September, prompting renewed concern about an undiversified long-term recession.

Expenses fell while domestic demand remained constant, reflecting an increase in corporate investment but also a decline in exports. The rate of growth is less than expectations and does not indicate a sixth straight quarter of expansion. 

Japan’s economy had maintained steady growth through the decades, with only brief spurts of expansion amidst long periods in the doldrums. Deflationary measures led shoppers to avoid spending on goods while prices fell which kept them cautious.

Recovery left the economy more dependent on exports for its recent recovery but high oil prices have reduced the growth rate by 0.2% implying products are becoming more expensive relative to where they started.

The first quarter of this year saw a steady increase in annual growth of 6.3%, with the second showing 1.1%. However, economists were expecting as much as 2% for this period. 

A significant event occurred around the Olympics, and capital spending became weaker. The government may now find it more difficult to raise taxes due to the massive public debt in Japan. As a result, it is recommended that the country invest more in growth, stimulate investment, and encourage more open trade.
smollm:1.7b:
Japanese growth grinds to a halt in the three months to September, sparking renewed concern about an economy not long out of a decade-long trough. Exports - the usual engine of recovery - faltered, while domestic demand stayed subdued and corporate investment also fell short. The growth falls well below expectations, but does mark a sixth straight quarter of expansion.
The economy had stagnated throughout the 1990s, experiencing only brief spurts of expansion amidst long periods in the doldrums. One result was deflation - prices falling rather than rising - which made Japanese shoppers cautious and kept them from spending. The effect was to leave the economy more dependent than ever on exports for its recent recovery. But high oil prices have knocked 0.2% off the growth rate, while the falling dollar means products shipped to the US are becoming relatively more expensive.
The performance for the third quarter marks a sharp downturn from earlier in the year. The first quarter showed annual growth of 6.3%, with the second showing 1.1%, and economists had been predicting as much as 2% this time around. "Exports slowed while capital spending became weaker," said Hiromichi Shirakawa, chief economist at UBS Securities in Tokyo. "Personal consumption looks good, but it was mainly due to temporary factors such as the Olympics." The government may now find it more difficult to raise taxes, a policy it will have to implement when the economy picks up to help deal with Japan's massive public debt.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about Japan's economic situation. Let me read through the whole thing first.

So, Japan's economy has been through a trough for the past decade. The growth dropped by almost zero in three months—only 0.1% annualized. That's super low compared to previous times when they had some expansion, right?

Looking at the output, exports were bad because prices are falling instead of rising, which makes people pause and save more. So, less spending from both consumers and businesses.

Corporations aren't investing much either. That's a problem because if you're not spending or investing, your economy might slow down.

The growth is way below expectations, but it does make Japan exit the early trough into a post-downturn phase—sixth straight quarter of expansion. So, they're seeing some improvement, but not just in exports.

But here's something else: oil prices are going up by 0.2% annually, which is bad for Japan. High oil prices mean cheaper imported goods, so when they import more from other countries, their products become cheaper for the US.

The dollar has fallen, making American products more expensive for Japan. That could hurt exports because people might prefer to buy domestically instead.

Economists were predicting a growth rate of around 2% this time, but actual growth was much lower—only 0.3%. So it's not looking great yet.

The third quarter performance is worse than expected. First and second quarters were actually better than the previous year's predictions. That could mean that maybe there are underlying issues or positive signals from the Olympics in the first quarter.

Hiromichi Shirakawa, a UBS economist, says exports did slow down but personal consumption was on track. But other factors like Olympics made it temporary. So while they might be able to recover, it's not without hitches.

The government needs to raise taxes more now because economic recovery is slow. That could help reduce public debt, which Japan has a large amount of.

So putting this all together, the main points are: Japan's economy is struggling with low growth and high oil prices, leading to deflation and slower exports. Expectations for growth are lower than anticipated, but the economy might recover in the post-downturn phase. However, public debt is a concern, so raising taxes now could help.
</think>

Japan's economy has experienced a significant drop in output with growth only 0.1% annualized, marking the start of a post-downturn phase. Deflation caused by falling prices and high oil prices have reduced spending, while domestic demand and corporate investment were also slow. Expectations for recovery are lower than anticipated, though Japan is entering the sixth straight quarter of expansion. Oil price increases and changing dollar values affected US imports, impacting exports despite better performance in Q1. The government may face challenges in raising taxes to aid economic recovery.
tinyllama:1.1b: Japanese growth has stalled for the third quarter, marked by subdued exports and weak capital spending. The decline in annual growth is sharply down from earlier in the year, while expectations were calling for as much as 2% expansion this time around. The economy appears to be suffering from a combination of factors, including high oil prices and falling exports, which are hurting demand. Shirakawa suggests that personal consumption remains good, but tax increases may become difficult to implement once the economy picks up. However, Japan's fiscal stance will remain under the spotlight as they work to deal with their massive public debt.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Japanese growth grinds to a halt: 0.1%, a annual rate of 0.3% - Exports: The usual engine of recovery stopped - Domestic demand stayed subdued, corporate investment fell short - Economy had stagnated throughout the 1990s, experiencing brief spurts of expansion amid long periods in the doldrums - One result was deflation - Prices falling rather than rising - High oil prices knocked off 0.2% off the growth rate, while the falling dollar means products shipped to the US are becoming relatively more expensive - The effect was to leave the economy more dependent than ever on exports for its recent recovery - But high oil prices have knocked off 0.2% off the growth rate.
phi:2.7b: Japan's growth in September slowed significantly, reaching just 0.1% annual rate, down from 1.3% during August and 2.7% in February. Exports faltered while domestic demand and investment weakened. The economy had been stagnant for most of the 1990s, leading to deflation and dependence on exports for recovery. High oil prices and a falling US dollar have affected Japan's growth rate. Economists are concerned about the future of Japan's public debt, as the government may find it difficult to raise taxes in a recovering economy.
orca-mini:3b: Japanese economic growth slowed down in the third quarter, coming in at just 0.1% on an annual rate, and marking a sixth straight quarter of expansion. While exports remained strong, domestic demand and corporate investment both fell short, as the economy struggled to keep up with high oil prices and a weaker dollar. The result was deflationary pressure, with Japanese shoppers becoming more cautious and the economy becoming even more dependent on exports for its recent recovery.
hermes3:3b: Japan economic growth 0.1% (0.3% ann.) in Q3, marking 6th straight quarter of expansion but far below expectations. Stagnation throughout 1990s led to deflation, boosting dependence on exports which now face challenges from high oil prices and falling dollar.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Growth in Japan slowed down to 0.1% in the three months from September, causing concerns about the economy after a decade-long stagnation. Exports, which usually drive recovery, faltered, and domestic demand remained subdued, with corporate investment also weak. This marks the sixth straight quarter of expansion, but highlights the dependence on exports for recent recovery, impacted by high oil prices and a falling dollar. The third quarter performance showed a sharp downturn from earlier in the year, with personal consumption mainly due to temporary factors.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Japan's economic growth stalled in the third quarter, with output rising just 0.1% amid weak exports, subdued domestic demand, and declining corporate investment. This marks the sixth consecutive quarter of expansion but falls short of expectations. Japan's economy, which struggled through the 1990s with deflation and weak consumer spending, has relied heavily on exports for recovery. However, high oil prices and a weaker dollar have hurt growth. The slowdown follows stronger growth earlier in the year, with economists expecting better results. The government may now face challenges in implementing tax increases needed to address Japan's large public debt.
stablelm2:1.6b: Japan's economic growth halted in Q3 after just 0.1% annual rate of 0.3%, surpassing six straight quarters of expansion. Exports fell while domestic demand remained subdued, causing deflation that discouraged spending. High oil prices and falling dollar affected growth negatively. The drop marks a sharp decline from earlier this year when annual growth was 6.3%. The government may face difficulties increasing taxes to deal with Japan's massive public debt.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Japanese economic growth stalled in Q3, recording just 0.1% annual growth due to faltering exports, subdued domestic demand, and reduced corporate investment. This contraction marks a sixth consecutive quarter of expansion but significantly underperforms earlier quarters' rates of 6.3% (Q1) and 1.1% (Q2), with economists anticipating no more than 2% growth this time. The economy, still recovering from a decade-long slump, remains heavily reliant on exports for growth. High oil prices and a weaker dollar have further dampened export competitiveness in the US market. This slowdown signals potential challenges for the government in raising taxes to manage public debt as the economy recovers.
reference: The growth falls well short of expectations, but does mark a sixth straight quarter of expansion.The first quarter showed annual growth of 6.3%, with the second showing 1.1%, and economists had been predicting as much as 2% this time around.The effect was to leave the economy more dependent than ever on exports for its recent recovery.The economy had stagnated throughout the 1990s, experiencing only brief spurts of expansion amid long periods in the doldrums.Growth in Japan evaporated in the three months to September, sparking renewed concern about an economy not long out of a decade-long trough.But high oil prices have knocked 0.2% off the growth rate, while the falling dollar means products shipped to the US are becoming relatively more expensive.
